text:
0 COMMENTS A person holds the new ZTE dual-screen smartphone at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona on Feb. 26, 2018. Photo: Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
South Korea’s former president decided not to appeal her 24-year prison sentence. Another former president had his assets frozen as a trial date approaches . (VOA, KBS, Yonhap)
Indonesia plans to limit cash to curtail bribery. (Bloomberg, Reuters)
A powerful Brazilian senator faces trial for allegedly accepting bribes ; the lawmaker said he was set up. Corruption in Brazil is causing Netflix problems. (AFP, Reuters, OCCRP, Atlantic)
Local cases: The head of an engineering firm allegedly enlisted his employees to donate to the New York City mayor’s 2013 campaign, according to a bribery indictment ; his lawyer declined to comment. His trial in a separate case is set for June. A former Detroit police official was jailed . A Bulgarian mayor was arrested ; the story didn’t contain a response. (NYP, NYDN, Newsday, TRD, release, ENR, DN, SG)
Cybercrime:
The suspected mastermind behind the theft of 600 computers to mine bitcoin in Iceland escaped prison and fled to Sweden in an airplane reportedly carrying the Icelandic premier. (Guardian)
Georgia’s governor is set to sign a cybersecurity bill. (Slate)
The Hong Kong Broadband Network was hacked . (SCMP)
A U.K. health service website was hacked . (BBC)
North Korea’s hacking hasn’t stopped amid the recent diplomacy . (Reuters, WP)
A cybercriminal was sentenced . (release)
Money Laundering:
Murdered Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia was investigating the island’s hugely profitable “passports for sale,” or golden visa, program before she was killed. An investigative journalism project started in her name continues . (OCCRP, Guardian, RadioNZ)
The U.K. parliament launched an investigation into alleged money-laundering breaches by the health minister. (Guardian, Sun, Reuters)
David Cohen, a former CIA deputy director who was the undersecretary of Treasury for terrorism and financial intelligence, is representing ABLV bank in its dispute with the U.S. The bank is accused of facilitating money laundering. The bank name appeared in a Maltese investigation. (LSM, LSM)
There are four candidates to become Latvia’s anti-money laundering chief. (LSM)
Concerns bitcoin is being used for money laundering are overblown , said Quebec’s chief scientist. (Forbes)
Could improving anti-money laundering legal regimes prevent war? (AEI)
Sanctions:
ZTE Corp. replaced its chief compliance officer when admitting it lied to the U.S. government about adhering to a settlement resolving export-controls violations. Chinese Internet users unleashed patriotic rhetoric and Beijing changed its chip plans. (SCMP, Reuters, Reuters)
U.S. sanctions on Russia sparked a crisis: 60,000 workers may not get paid and there’s a stockpile of aluminum. Majorities back tougher sanctions on Russia. Moscow is considering counter-sanctions and a potential nationalization . (Bloomberg, Reuters, ABC, ES, Reuters)
U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio (R., Fla.) wants tougher sanctions on Cuba. (ENH)
The U.S. is considering sanction s on Chinese officials for human-rights abuses. (WP)
Global finance ministers promised to maximize economic pressure on North Korea. (Reuters)
The EU is edging closer to new sanctions on Iran as another nuclear-deal deadline approaches. (Reuters, DB)
Transparency:
Gunvor agreed to disclose the payments it makes to governments. (Bloomberg)
Whistleblowers:
A former FBI agent pleaded guilty to leaking classified information. (release, Politico)
A blunder by Oxfam revealed the names of whistleblowers who exposed sexual misconduct in Haiti. (Times)
General Anti-Corruption:
There’s a battle brewing in Congress over whether to protect the U.S. special counsel from a potential firing. A deeper look at how Facebook was used in the 2016 election. (Politico, Wired)
Russian authorities cut off access to encrypted messaging app Telegram, causing web-service problems . Iran banned use of the app. (Guardian, Bloomberg, BBC, AP, DB, Reuters, RFE/RL)
A U.S. lawmaker backed bills in Congress that would benefit the pharmaceutical company of which he is the lead shareholder. (DB)
Venezuela arrested two Chevron employees in what it said was a corruption purge . Chevron said it contacted authorities to get information. (AP)
FIFA said it’s monitoring the situation concerning the detainment of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s soccer boss. (BBC, DM)
A podcast called Trump Inc. follows how the president’s businesses fare while he’s in office. (Stranger, ProPublica, DB, BuzzFeed)
